_header: It is no right all other lusts to lose
_description: ‘Balade by Chaucer’ on swiving — three stanzas rhyme royal

BLHar7578.First Lines:
It is no Right all othr lustes to leseThis mery month of may for
                    myssinge of on cas…
BLHar7578.Last Lines:
…And ther in dompe as depe as man myght dyueThis holde I bette
                    thanne laboure as a Reue
BLHar7578.Editions:
Brusendorff,  Aage. 
             The Chaucer Tradition.
         Copenhagen, 1925; repr. Oxford: Clarendon, 1967: 280-1.

BLAdd16165.First Lines:
Hit is no right alle oþer lustes to leeseþis moneþe
                    of May for missyng of one cas…
BLAdd16165.Last Lines:
…To fonde to dompe als deepe as man may dyeveþus holde I
                    bett þan labour as a Reeve
BLAdd16165.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             “Balade by Chaucer.” 
             Atheneum
         57 (Feb. 18, 1871): 34: 210 (st. 1, 2 only).
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             Jyl of Breyntford’s Testament and Other Poems.
         London, 1871; privately circulated: 34-5.
Brusendorff,  Aage. 
             The Chaucer Tradition.
         Copenhagen, 1925; repr. Oxford: Clarendon, 1967: 280-1.
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Omissions from the Editions of Chaucer.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         19 (1904): 35-38: 38.
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards.  
             “‘Chaucer’s Chronicle,’ John Shirley, and the Canon of
                Chaucer’s Shorter Poems.” 
             Studies in the Age of Chaucer
         20 (1998): 201-18: 217.
